page.title: 13MRS.PUNTINS (continued)
page.content: Mrs. Puntins said that rationing was shocking and there was very little to eat. The kitchen differs a great deal. Things are made easy by having electric cookers and fast boiling things and easy to clean things that she didn't have when she was young.When she was a little girl she couldn't buy tins of food; you bought everything fresh, so she was often sent out for the groceries. Mrs. Puntins prefers the old coinage because she got more to the pound; she got 240 pennies then but now she only gets 100. Nowadays Mrs.Puntins has to have a special diet. She has to buy meat, fish and anything with no fat in it and brown bread. She bakes her own cakes so she knows what she is eating. She intends to stay in the same house now for the rest of her life.
